snippet.textDisplay: I was pleasantly surprised to see the PocketGo in this video! I’ve been enjoying mine, and I recommend it to anyone looking for a relatively inexpensive, portable retro device. If you do get it, make sure one of the first things you do is copy the roms to your own microSD (i lost a few hours of saves when the provided microSD died). There are a few tutorials online for installing the latest CFW to a fresh card as well. Also, the TV out port currently only plays audio through the TV’s speakers (no video). Great for playing in bed!
snippet.textOriginal: I was pleasantly surprised to see the PocketGo in this video! I’ve been enjoying mine, and I recommend it to anyone looking for a relatively inexpensive, portable retro device. If you do get it, make sure one of the first things you do is copy the roms to your own microSD (i lost a few hours of saves when the provided microSD died). There are a few tutorials online for installing the latest CFW to a fresh card as well. Also, the TV out port currently only plays audio through the TV’s speakers (no video). Great for playing in bed!

snippet.textDisplay: yeah no thanks, no joystick at all, apart from how terrible the entire thing is. you guys shouldve taken a look at the odroid go advance. costs WAY less and has at least one joystick so psp and ps1 work properly. this thing isnt worth it AT ALL. the build quality is terrible, the diy version isnt cheaper for whatever reason, the screen isnt even 720p while sub 200$ smartphones (wich are more powerful as well) have 1080p screens now. no joystick, and you have to go through a giant amount of tinkering to get it working. for 250$ id expect a perfect experience. those guys just threw retropie on a rbp3 and charged a stupid amount of money for it. theres way cheaper options, and while those arent perfect as well, at least you get a good deal.

snippet.textDisplay:
Having built a tablet based on the raspberry pi 4 recently for SIGNIFICANTLY less that the cost of this thing, it amuses me that a "professional" product has all the same limitations and issues that come along with using an rpi as a mobile platform. It looks like they just threw a bone-stock distro of retropi on this thing and didn't bother to do any modifications to handle battery monitoring or soft-shutdown on low-battery. Also, the case looks like absolute crap for the price. I paid $24 for a tablet case on amazon that is much sturdier and well-built than that thing.

And guess what? It will only take a couple of hard-shutdowns before the memory card will get corrupted and you will have to start over from scratch - that is well-known issue with the raspberry pi.
snippet.textOriginal:
Having built a tablet based on the raspberry pi 4 recently for SIGNIFICANTLY less that the cost of this thing, it amuses me that a "professional" product has all the same limitations and issues that come along with using an rpi as a mobile platform.  It looks like they just threw a bone-stock distro of retropi on this thing and didn't bother to do any modifications to handle battery monitoring or soft-shutdown on low-battery.  Also, the case looks like absolute crap for the price.  I paid $24 for a tablet case on amazon that is much sturdier and well-built than that thing.   

And guess what?  It will only take a couple of hard-shutdowns before the memory card will get corrupted and you will have to start over from scratch - that is well-known issue with the raspberry pi.

snippet.textDisplay: "why wouldnt we just put the micro SD card in the computer" that isnt such a bad idea untillyou think about filesystems, the raspberry pi SD card images have 2 partitions, boot and rootfs. The boot partition is just a standard FAT32 filesystem but as we are dealing with linux, rootfs is obviously EXT4 and as you probably know, windows cant nativly read EXT4. One idea could be to have another partition on the SD card for all of the games that is a filesystem like FAT32 what would then be readable by windows what would make that idea a possibility (so I guess there is a suggestion to Creoqode)
snippet.textOriginal: "why wouldnt we just put the micro SD card in the computer" that isnt such a bad idea untillyou think about filesystems, the raspberry pi SD card images have 2 partitions, boot and rootfs. The boot partition is just a standard FAT32 filesystem but as we are dealing with linux, rootfs is obviously EXT4 and as you probably know, windows cant nativly read EXT4. One idea could be to have another partition on the SD card for all of the games that is a filesystem like FAT32 what would then be readable by windows what would make that idea a possibility (so I guess there is a suggestion to Creoqode)

snippet.textDisplay: 480p is awesome for retro gaming. Scales 240p perfectly and leaves room for scanlines without messing up the scale. Lots of older games are also in 480i or 480p (6th Gen mostly). Higher res is actually worse for retro games and lag is created when scaling has to be done. This device seems awesome.
snippet.textOriginal: 480p is awesome for retro gaming. Scales 240p perfectly and leaves room for scanlines without messing up the scale. Lots of older games are also in 480i or 480p (6th Gen mostly). Higher res is actually worse for retro games and lag is created when scaling has to be done. This device seems awesome.

snippet.textOriginal: Buy a PS Vita instead

snippet.textDisplay:
A rather sad creation, that. If you want better emulation on the go, get an RG350. Not only does it play anything up to PS1 pretty swell, it also has TWO analog sticks to play Ape Escape (& other analog dependent titles) and stereo speakers. 320x240 60Hz IPS display and FOUR shoulder buttons for L1/L2 & R1/R2. I think the buttons feel fine, if not a bit too clicky.

The OS isn't quite perfect and does have issues with some PS1 ROMs in my experience. It does not support N64 yet, and it's a mite too small for gigantic hands such as mine.

It has several ports that are non-functioning, but are potential for firmware updates to enable them and other things.

(I haven't perfected my PS1 setup yet, so it may just be a setting/filetype I goofed. Reviews I've seen around YT seem to have no issues like me.)
snippet.textOriginal:
A rather sad creation, that. If you want better emulation on the go, get an RG350. Not only does it play anything up to PS1 pretty swell, it also has TWO analog sticks to play Ape Escape (& other analog dependent titles) and stereo speakers. 320x240 60Hz IPS display and FOUR shoulder buttons for L1/L2 & R1/R2. I think the buttons feel fine, if not a bit too clicky.

The OS isn't quite perfect and does have issues with some PS1 ROMs in my experience. It does not support N64 yet, and it's a mite too small for gigantic hands such as mine.

It has several ports that are non-functioning, but are potential for firmware updates to enable them and other things.

(I haven't perfected my PS1 setup yet, so it may just be a setting/filetype I goofed. Reviews I've seen around YT seem to have no issues like me.)

snippet.textDisplay: a used psvita is the way to go. Excellent controls (plus 2 analog sticks), supports up to PS1 and PSP games (and, well, PSVita games, duh), can stream to a pc (and vice versa: there's a community port of moonlight), expandable storage (even with microSD if you buy the adapter), built-in bluetooth and wifi modules (heck, even 3G on the 3G model). Costs 100$ in the US, even less in Europe.
snippet.textOriginal: a used psvita is the way to go. Excellent controls (plus 2 analog sticks), supports up to PS1 and PSP games (and, well, PSVita games, duh), can stream to a pc (and vice versa: there's a community port of moonlight), expandable storage (even with microSD if you buy the adapter), built-in bluetooth and wifi modules (heck, even 3G on the 3G model). Costs 100$ in the US, even less in Europe.

snippet.textDisplay:
ok what the heck .... "there's nothing else quite like it, doesn't it?"


EVER HEARD of Retroflag GPi case ... approach a bit different price different, better build quality, true retro look, cost just a bit more than a fourth of the Lyra price (70$, been around for a bit more time ... has WiFi and BT (provided you use a Zero W ) although use a RPi Zero (W or non W ), which is the only cons, with the screen size ) since a Zero W offer less oomph than a CM3L transfert the roms via shared network


i am using one i got in a full bundle, 100ish $ for bundles, with a Zero W (well actually got 2 Zero W with although it was mentioned only 1 in the delivery, yaaay free stuff), 4 Panasonic Eneloop Pro (use 3 but can be powered externally from a powerbank via the include cable), one uSD 32gb UHS-I U3 card, play all retro games from consoles i owned up to the PSX (and if it's above a PS2 it's not retro enough)


http://retroflag.com/GPi-CASE.html


tho if the maker of the Lyra were smart ... they wouldn't use a RPi CM and just mod a RPi4 or a RPi 3 A+ like a Zero used in the GPi case, the Zero need to be a without GPIO pin for a Pi 4 it would need more extensive work but for a 3 A+ just like a Zero, removing GPIO pin header and using a Pogo pin contact board in the Lyra (and lower the price by at least half what they ask for the actual model)
snippet.textOriginal:
ok what the heck .... "there's nothing else quite like it, doesn't it?"

http://retroflag.com/GPi-CASE.html

snippet.textDisplay:
That's a ridiculous pricetag. For that money you can get a cheap Android phone + controller with phone holder and do the same, just better.
And I've actually built a mobile retro gaming console based on a Pi Zero W (with WiFi and Bluetooth) for like $50 in materials; just mine also has an HDMI out, for a Switch type experience.
